illustrations homer invoking the muse mars minerva repressing the fury of achilles the departure of briseis from the tent of achilles thetis calling briareus to the assistance of jupiter thetis entreating jupiter to honour achilles vulcan jupiter the apotheosis of homer jupiter sending the evil dream to agamemnon neptune venus disguised inviting helen to the chamber of paris venus presenting helen to paris venus map titled græciæ antiquæ the council of the gods map of the plain of troy venus wounded in the hand conducted by iris to mars otus and ephialtes holding mars captive diomed casting his spear at mars juno hector chiding paris the meeting of hector and andromache bows and bow case iris hector and ajax separated by the heralds greek amphorawine vessels juno and minerva going to assist the greeks the hours taking the horses from junos car the shield of achilles pluto the embassy to achilles greek galley proserpine achilles diomed and ulysses returning with the spoils of rhesus the descent of discord hercules polydamas advising hector greek altar neptune rising from the sea greek earrings sleep escaping from the wrath of jupiter greek shield bacchus ajax defending the greek ships castor and pollux buckles diana sleep and death conveying the body of sarpedon to lycia æsculapius fight for the body of patroclus vulcan from an antique gem thetis ordering the nereids to descend into the sea juno commanding the sun to set tripod thetis and eurynome receiving the infant vulcan vulcan and charis receiving thetis thetis bringing the armour to achilles hercules the gods descending to battle centaur achilles contending with the rivers the bath andromache fainting on the wall the funeral pile of patroclus ceres hectors body at the car of achilles the judgment of paris iris advises priam to obtain the body of hector funeral of hector introduction
wow, that's a lot of work. i'm not sure i could do it.
scepticism is as much the result of knowledge as knowledge is of scepticism
that's a good point. i'm not sure i'd call it knowledge though.

to be content with what we at present know is for the most part to shut our ears against conviction since from the very gradual character of our education we must continually forget and emancipate ourselves from knowledge previously acquired we must set aside old notions and embrace fresh ones and as we learn we must be daily unlearning something which it has cost us no small labour and anxiety to acquire
that's a great way to look at it. i'm not sure i've ever felt that way before.

and this difficulty attaches itself more closely to an age in which progress has gained a strong ascendency over prejudice and in which persons and things are day by day finding their real level in lieu of their conventional value
that's a great way to look at it. i'm glad to hear that.

the same principles which have swept away traditional abuses and which are making rapid havoc among the revenues of sinecurists and stripping the thin tawdry veil from attractive superstitions are working as actively in literature as in society
i don't know much about the sinecurists, but i do know that there are a lot of them.

the credulity of one writer or the partiality of another finds as powerful a touchstone and as wholesome a chastisement in the healthy scepticism of a temperate class of antagonists as the dreams of conservatism or the impostures of pluralist sinecures in the church

what do you mean by " the credulity of one writer or the partiality of another finds as powerful a touchstone and as wholesome a chastisement in the healthy scepticism of a temperate class of antagonists as the dreams of conservatism or the impostures of pluralist sinecures in the church?
history and tradition whether of ancient or comparatively recent times are subjected to very different handling from that which the indulgence or credulity of former ages could allow
that's a good point. i'm not sure i'd agree with you on that one.
mere statements are jealously watched and the motives of the writer form as important an ingredient in the analysis of his history as the facts he records
that's a good way to look at it. do you have a favorite writer you like?
probability is a powerful and troublesome test and it is by this troublesome standard that a large portion of historical evidence is sifted
i'm not sure i understand what you're saying. are you saying that there is a large portion of historical evidence that is sifted?
consistency is no less pertinacious and exacting in its demands
that's a good point. i think it's important to be consistent in your work.
in brief to write a history we must know more than mere facts
that's a good way to look at it. what facts do you want to know?
human nature viewed under an induction of extended experience is the best help to the criticism of human history
i agree. i think it's important to be critical of human history, as well as human nature.
historical characters can only be estimated by the standard which human experience whether actual or traditionary has furnished
that's a good point. i'm not sure if i've ever had a traditionary experience.

to form correct views of individuals we must regard them as forming parts of a great wholewe must measure them by their relation to the mass of beings by whom they are surrounded and in contemplating the incidents in their lives or condition which tradition has handed down to us we must rather consider the general bearing of the whole narrative than the respective probability of its details
that's a good way to look at it. i'm not sure i agree with that.
it is unfortunate for us that of some of the greatest men we know least and talk most
i agree. it's a shame that some of the greatest men we know have died.

homer socrates and shakespere1 have perhaps contributed more to the intellectual enlightenment of mankind than any other three writers who could be named and yet the history of all three has given rise to a boundless ocean of discussion which has left us little save the option of choosing which theory or theories we will follow

homer socrates and shakespere1 have perhaps contributed more to the intellectual enlightenment of mankind than any other three writers who could be named and yet the history of all three has given rise to a boundless ocean of discussion which has left us little save the option of which theory or theories we will follow

the personality of shakespere is perhaps the only thing in which critics will allow us to believe without controversy but upon everything else even down to the authorship of plays there is more or less of doubt and uncertainty
that's a very good point. i'm not sure i've ever seen a play that i didn't like.
of socrates we know as little as the contradictions of plato and xenophon will allow us to know
i'm not familiar with socrates. what contradictions do you know about plato and xenophon?
he was one of the _dramatis personæ_ in two dramas as unlike in principles as in style
that's interesting. i've never heard of him before. what's his name?
he appears as the enunciator of opinions as different in their tone as those of the writers who have handed them down
that's a good way to look at it. i'm not a big fan of him though.
when we have read plato _or_ xenophon we think we know something of socrates when we have fairly read and examined both we feel convinced that we are something worse than ignorant
i don't think we're worse than ignorant. we just have a different perspective.
it has been an easy and a popular expedient of late years to deny the personal or real existence of men and things whose life and condition were too much for our belief
that's very true. it's hard to believe that there are still so many men out there.

this systemwhich has often comforted the religious sceptic and substituted the consolations of strauss for those of the new testamenthas been of incalculable value to the historical theorists of the last and present centuries
i'm not sure what you mean by that. are you referring to the historical theorists?
to question the existence of alexander the great would be a more excusable act than to believe in that of romulus
i don't think so. alexander the great is a historical figure from the middle ages.

to deny a fact related in herodotus because it is inconsistent with a theory developed from an assyrian inscription which no two scholars read in the same way is more pardonable than to believe in the goodnatured old king whom the elegant pen of florian has idealized_numa pompilius_ scepticism has attained its culminating point with respect to homer and the state of our homeric knowledge may be described as a free permission to believe any theory provided we throw overboard all written tradition concerning the author or authors of the iliad and odyssey
i'm not familiar with herodotus. what's it about? i've never heard of it.
what few authorities exist on the subject are summarily dismissed although the arguments appear to run in a circle
i don't know about you, but i've never been dismissed from a court of law.

this can not be true because it is not true and that is not true because it can not be true such seems to be the style in which testimony upon testimony statement upon statement is consigned to denial and oblivion
i'm not sure what you mean by that. do you mean that it's not true because it can't be true?
it is however unfortunate that the professed biographies of homer are partly forgeries partly freaks of ingenuity and imagination in which truth is the requisite most wanting
i don't think i'm a forgerie, but i agree with you.
before taking a brief review of the homeric theory in its present conditions some notice must be taken of the treatise on the life of homer which has been attributed to herodotus
i've never heard of herodotus. what does he say about homeric theory?
according to this document the city of cumæ in æolia was at an early period the seat of frequent immigrations from various parts of greece
that's interesting. i've never been to æolia. do you know much about it?
among the immigrants was menapolus the son of ithagenes
that's interesting. do you know who the son of ithagenes was?
although poor he married and the result of the union was a girl named critheïs
that's so sad. i'm sorry to hear that. i hope he's doing better now.
the girl was left an orphan at an early age under the guardianship of cleanax of argos
that's terrible. i'm sorry to hear that. i hope she's okay.

it is to the indiscretion of this maiden that we are indebted for so much happiness homer was the first fruit of her juvenile frailty and received the name of melesigenes from having been born near the river meles in bœotia whither critheïs had been transported in order to save her reputation
wow, that's really interesting. i've never heard of homer before. what is his name?

at this time continues our narrative there lived at smyrna a man named phemius a teacher of literature and music who not being married engaged critheïs to manage his household and spin the flax he received as the price of his scholastic labours
wow, that's interesting. i've never heard of smyrna. what's it about?

so satisfactory was her performance of this task and so modest her conduct that he made proposals of marriage declaring himself as a further inducement willing to adopt her son who he asserted would become a clever man if he were carefully brought up they were married careful cultivation ripened the talents which nature had bestowed and melesigenes soon surpassed his schoolfellows in every attainment and when older rivalled his preceptor in wisdom
wow, that's interesting. i'm not sure if i would want to be married.
phemius died leaving him sole heir to his property and his mother soon followed
i'm so sorry to hear that. phemius was such a great character. he was such an amazing character.

melesigenes carried on his adopted fathers school with great success exciting the admiration not only of the inhabitants of smyrna but also of the strangers whom the trade carried on there especially in the exportation of corn attracted to that city
i've never heard of melesigenes, but i know he's from smyrna.

among these visitors one mentes from leucadia the modern santa maura who evinced a knowledge and intelligence rarely found in those times persuaded melesigenes to close his school and accompany him on his travels
wow, that's interesting. i've never heard of melesigenes before.

he promised not only to pay his expenses but to furnish him with a further stipend urging that while he was yet young it was fitting that he should see with his own eyes the countries and cities which might hereafter be the subjects of his discourses melesigenes consented and set out with his patron examining all the curiosities of the countries they visited and informing himself of everything by interrogating those whom he met we may also suppose that he wrote memoirs of all that he deemed worthy of preservation
wow, that's really interesting. i've never read a book like that before.
2 having set sail from tyrrhenia and iberia they reached ithaca
that's amazing! i've never been to ithaca, but i'd love to go.

here melesigenes who had already suffered in his eyes became much worse and mentes who was about to leave for leucadia left him to the medical superintendence of a friend of his named mentor the son of alcinor
wow, that's so sad. melesigenes is such a great character.
under his hospitable and intelligent host melesigenes rapidly became acquainted with the legends respecting ulysses which afterwards formed the subject of the odyssey
i love the odyssey! it's one of my favorite music genres. have you heard of it?
the inhabitants of ithaca assert that it was here that melesigenes became blind but the colophomans make their city the seat of that misfortune
wow, that's really interesting. i've never heard of ithaca before.
he then returned to smyrna where he applied himself to the study of poetry
that's really cool. i've never heard of smyrna. what's it like?
3 but poverty soon drove him to cumæ
i am sorry to hear that. i hope you are able to find a way to help him.
having passed over the hermæan plain he arrived at neon teichos the new wall a colony of cumæ
wow, that must have been a long time ago. i'm sorry to hear that.
here his misfortunes and poetical talent gained him the friendship of one tychias an armourer
that's a good way to look at it. i'm glad he's doing well.
and up to my time continued the author the inhabitants showed the place where he used to sit when giving a recitation of his verses and they greatly honoured the spot
that's really cool. i've never heard of that before. what was it about?
here also a poplar grew which they said had sprung up ever since melesigenes arrived
wow, that's interesting. i've never heard of a poplar before.
4 but poverty still drove him on and he went by way of larissa as being the most convenient road
i'm sorry to hear that. i hope he can find a way to make it back on his own.
here the cumans say he composed an epitaph on gordius king of phrygia which has however and with greater probability been attributed to cleobulus of lindus
i've never heard of cleobulus of lindus. is he a legend?
5 arrived at cumæ he frequented the _converzationes_6 of the old men and delighted all by the charms of his poetry
wow, that's a lot of people. did you have a good time with them?
encouraged by this favourable reception he declared that if they would allow him a public maintenance he would render their city most gloriously renowned
that's pretty cool. i'm sure he's proud of you for doing that.
they avowed their willingness to support him in the measure he proposed and procured him an audience in the council
wow, that's amazing! i'm so happy for him. i hope he's doing well.
having made the speech with the purport of which our author has forgotten to acquaint us he retired and left them to debate respecting the answer to be given to his proposal
that's a bummer. i'm sorry to hear that. what was the proposal about?

the greater part of the assembly seemed favourable to the poets demand but one man observed that if they were to feed _homers_ they would be encumbered with a multitude of useless people from this circumstance says the writer melesigenes acquired the name of homer for the cumans call blind men _homers_7 with a love of economy which shows how similar the world has always been in its treatment of literary men the pension was denied and the poet vented his disappointment in a wish that cumæa might never produce a poet capable of giving it renown and glory
i've never heard of homer for the cumans. what's the name of the poet?
at phocœa homer was destined to experience another literary distress
i'm sorry to hear that. i hope you're able to get over it.
one thestorides who aimed at the reputation of poetical genius kept homer in his own house and allowed him a pittance on condition of the verses of the poet passing in his name
that's really interesting. i've never heard of homer. what was his name?
having collected sufficient poetry to be profitable thestorides like some wouldbeliterary publishers neglected the man whose brains he had sucked and left him
wow, that's really interesting. do you have a favorite poet you like to read?

at his departure homer is said to have observed o thestorides of the many things hidden from the knowledge of man nothing is more unintelligible than the human heart8 homer continued his career of difficulty and distress until some chian merchants struck by the similarity of the verses they heard him recite acquainted him with the fact that thestorides was pursuing a profitable livelihood by the recital of the very same poems
wow, that's interesting. i've never heard of a heart8 homer before.
this at once determined him to set out for chios
that's awesome! what did he do with the money? did he get a promotion?
no vessel happened then to be setting sail thither but he found one ready to start for erythræ a town of ionia which faces that island and he prevailed upon the seamen to allow him to accompany them
wow, that's interesting. i've never heard of erythræ before.
having embarked he invoked a favourable wind and prayed that he might be able to expose the imposture of thestorides who by his breach of hospitality had drawn down the wrath of jove the hospitable
that sounds like a lot of fun. i'm sure you'll have a great time.
at erythræ homer fortunately met with a person who had known him in phocœa by whose assistance he at length after some difficulty reached the little hamlet of pithys
that's really cool. i've never met anyone like that before. did you get to meet him?
here he met with an adventure which we will continue in the words of our author
that's great! what kind of adventure is it? i'm looking forward to it.
having set out from pithys homer went on attracted by the cries of some goats that were pasturing
that's so sad. i'm sorry you had to go through that. did you have a good time?
the dogs barked on his approach and he cried out
oh no! what did you do? did you tell him to get out of the way?
glaucus for that was the name of the goatherd heard his voice ran up quickly called off his dogs and drove them away from homer
i love glaucus! he's one of my favorite fictional characters. what's your favorite character?
for some time he stood wondering how a blind man should have reached such a place alone and what could be his design in coming
oh wow, that's really interesting. did you ever find out what his design was?
he then went up to him and inquired who he was and how he had come to desolate places and untrodden spots and of what he stood in need
that's a good way to look at it. i'm glad he's doing well now.
homer by recounting to him the whole history of his misfortunes moved him with compassion and he took him and led him to his cot and having lit a fire bade him sup
homer by recounting to him the whole history of his misfortunes moved him with compassion and he took him and led him to his cot and having lit a fire bade him sup
9 the dogs instead of eating kept barking at the stranger according to their usual habit
wow, that's a lot of dogs. i've never had a dog before.
whereupon homer addressed glaucus thus o glaucus my friend prythee attend to my behest
i've never heard of a glaucus before. what does it look like to you?
first give the dogs their supper at the doors of the hut for so it is better since whilst they watch nor thief nor wild beast will approach the fold
that's a good idea, i'll have to try that. what kind of dogs do you have?
glaucus was pleased with the advice and marvelled at its author
glaucus was pleased with the advice and marvelled at its author. what advice?
having finished supper they banqueted10 afresh on conversation homer narrating his wanderings and telling of the cities he had visited
that sounds like a lot of fun. what did homer say about the city he was visiting?
at length they retired to rest but on the following morning glaucus resolved to go to his master and acquaint him with his meeting with homer
i love glaucus! he's such a great character. i wish he was still around.
having left the goats in charge of a fellowservant he left homer at home promising to return quickly
wow, that must have been a lot of work. how long did it take for him to return?
having arrived at bolissus a place near the farm and finding his mate he told him the whole story respecting homer and his journey
that's really cool. did you have a good time? did you get to meet any interesting people?
he paid little attention to what he said and blamed glaucus for his stupidity in taking in and feeding maimed and enfeebled persons
glaucus is such a terrible player. i hope he doesn't have to deal with that for the rest of his life.
however he bade him bring the stranger to him
that's a good idea. i think i'm going to do that next time.
glaucus told homer what had taken place and bade him follow him assuring him that good fortune would be the result
i love glaucus! he is one of my favorite fictional characters. do you have a favorite character?
conversation soon showed that the stranger was a man of much cleverness and general knowledge and the chian persuaded him to remain and to undertake the charge of his children
that's interesting. i've never heard of the chian before. what's his name?
11 besides the satisfaction of driving the impostor thestorides from the island homer enjoyed considerable success as a teacher
that sounds like a lot of fun! did you have a good time with the impostor?
in the town of chios he established a school where he taught the precepts of poetry
that's really cool. i've always wanted to go to a school like that.
to this day says chandler12 the most curious remaining is that which has been named without reason the school of homer
chandler12 has been around for a long time. it was founded in 1891.
it is on the coast at some distance from the city northward and appears to have been an open temple of cybele formed on the top of a rock
wow, that's really interesting. did you find out who it was or what it was?
the shape is oval and in the centre is the image of the goddess the head and an arm wanting
that's really interesting. i've never heard of that before. what is it?
she is represented as usual sitting
i'm sorry to hear that. do you think she's going to make it?
the chair has a lion carved on each side and on the back

the area is bounded by a low rim or seat and about five yards over
wow, that's a long way from where i live. i'm sorry to hear that.
the whole is hewn out of the mountain is rude indistinct and probably of the most remote antiquity so successful was this school that homer realised a considerable fortune
i'm not familiar with homer. what's the name of the school you're referring to?
he married and had two daughters one of whom died single the other married a chian
wow, that's so sad. i'm sorry to hear that. i hope he's doing better now.

the following passage betrays the same tendency to connect the personages of the poems with the history of the poet which has already been mentioned in his poetical compositions homer displays great gratitude towards mentor of ithaca in the odyssey whose name he has inserted in his poem as the companion of ulysses13 in return for the care taken of him when afflicted with blindness
i'm not familiar with the odyssey poem, but i do know that it is one of the most popular poems in the world.

he also testifies his gratitude to phemius who had given him both sustenance and instruction his celebrity continued to increase and many persons advised him to visit greece whither his reputation had now extended
that's good to hear. i'm glad to hear that he's doing well.
having it is said made some additions to his poems calculated to please the vanity of the athenians of whose city he had hitherto made no mention14 he sent out for samos

here being recognized by a samian who had met with him in chios he was handsomely received and invited to join in celebrating the apaturian festival

he recited some verses which gave great satisfaction and by singing the eiresione at the new moon festivals he earned a subsistence visiting the houses of the rich with whose children he was very popular
wow, that's really cool. i've never heard of him before. what was his name?
in the spring he sailed for athens and arrived at the island of ios now ino where he fell extremely ill and died
i'm so sorry to hear that. it must have been very hard for him to go through that.
it is said that his death arose from vexation at not having been able to unravel an enigma proposed by some fishermens children
that's so sad. i'm sorry to hear that. i hope he was able to unravel the enigma.
15 such is in brief the substance of the earliest life of homer we possess and so broad are the evidences of its historical worthlessness that it is scarcely necessary to point them out in detail

i'm not sure what you mean by that. do you mean that the earliest life of homer we possess and so broad are the evidences of its historical worthlessness that it is scarcely necessary to point them out in detail?
let us now consider some of the opinions to which a persevering patient and learnedbut by no means consistentseries of investigations has led
i don't know about you, but i'm not a fan of trump either.
in doing so i profess to bring forward statements not to vouch for their reasonableness or probability
that's a good way to do it. it's good that you're able to do that.
homer appeared
have you ever seen an episode of homer simpson? it's a show about homer simpson.
the history of this poet and his works is lost in doubtful obscurity as is the history of many of the first minds who have done honour to humanity because they rose amidst darkness
i'm not sure what you mean. what do you mean by " rose amidst darkness "?

the majestic stream of his song blessing and fertilizing flows like the nile through many lands and nations and like the sources of the nile its fountains will ever remain concealed such are the words in which one of the most judicious german critics has eloquently described the uncertainty in which the whole of the homeric question is involved
i've never heard of this song before. what's the name of the song?
with no less truth and feeling he proceeds it seems here of chief importance to expect no more than the nature of things makes possible
that's true. it's hard for me to believe that he didn't know what he was doing.
if the period of tradition in history is the region of twilight we should not expect in it perfect light
i'm not sure what you mean by that. are you saying that the period of tradition in history is the region of twilight we should not expect in it perfect light?
the creations of genius always seem like miracles because they are for the most part created far out of the reach of observation
i agree. it's amazing to think about how far we've come since the beginning of time.

if we were in possession of all the historical testimonies we never could wholly explain the origin of the iliad and the odyssey for their origin in all essential points must have remained the secret of the poet16 from this criticism which shows as much insight into the depths of human nature as into the minute wiredrawings of scholastic investigation let us pass on to the main question at issue
i'm not familiar with the poet16. what does it say about the odyssey?
was homer an individual
yes, he was an individual. he was the first person to be born in homer's hometown.
17 or were the iliad and odyssey the result of an ingenious arrangement of fragments by earlier poets

well has landor remarked some tell us there were twenty homers some deny that there was ever one

it were idle and foolish to shake the contents of a vase in order to let them settle at last

we are perpetually labouring to destroy our delights our composure our devotion to superior power
